text: - Hello and welcome to Community Chats.

I'm Aley Hammer and today we're
joined with Brady Jacobsen,

the GM of digital and customer
experience over at Vocus.
Brady, welcome to the show.

Can you start by telling
us a little bit about Vocus
and also your role in the business?
- We're a leading specialist provider
of fiber and network solutions
and really focused on building
a world-class, purpose-built network

that's helping industry do
more, go further, grow faster.
My role is the general manager
of digital and customer experience.

It's a really exciting one
and it's one that puts me

and those I have the
pleasure of working with

front and center in
developing our capabilities

in the areas that supports
that fantastic network

and our digital future
for people in our cities,
in our regions and remote areas.

- What an exciting time
to be the GM of Vocus,

and Brady, can you talk us
through Vocus's future strategy

and the role that partners
like AWS play in this?

- Yeah, our future, or our
strategy is called Future State,
and Vocus has grown through acquisition,

which means it's given
us this rich tapestry
of products, technologies, capabilities,

and some exceptional
talent within our business.

The Future State program's
really focused on

fundamentally changing
the customer experience,

and that's gonna be done
through simplifying,
modernizing and consolidating our network
and the solutions we offer on top of that,

and it'll also deliver
brilliant simplicity

to our customers, making
it really simple and easy

to connect to these
world-class network solutions.

There's three areas that
we focus on in doing that.
It's first to consolidate and simplify,

where we're consolidating our
network and our edge locations
with some really amazing new technology

to provide greater
capacity and resilience.
The next one is to enable our customers

with best-of-breed solutions,
like things like AWS,

and making sure that those
best-in-breed solutions

provide an ecosystem
which equally partners
can connect into as well,

and that's gonna deliver
automation and an open platform
that makes it really easy for customers

to work on our network
through orchestration
and software-defined networking,
and the final piece is digitization,

which is to make that end-user
experience a lot easier

through end-to-end digital
tools and solutions,

which makes it modular
and also cloud based

with some of our BSS systems
that we'll use as well.

It's really nice that
AWS is a key part of that
and one of the earliest parts
of that implementation as well.
- I personally love that you've actually
named your strategy Future State.
That's very fitting, and Brady,

you recently announced your
migration to Amazon Connect.
Why did you choose Connect

and how has this actually
changed your customer
and also your staff experience?
- Yeah, we sure did, Aley.

We consolidated five
disparate contact center

telephony platforms to Amazon
Connect in about two months

and it was one of the easiest
technical implementations
that I've done in my career

of doing customer-orientated
technology change,
and we used a partner called SmartSpeak

and had a small but really
motivated internal team
that helped us get there.
I had to deliberate long and hard
about the shift to Connect.
I'd used another cloud telephony provider
for many, many years,
and what I found in thinking about
that solution versus Amazon Connect,

it ultimately ended up being
a, while we deliberated,
it ended up being a pretty easy decision.
I did my research one evening.

I built my own contact center,
like so many other people
who jump onto the Connect platform,

and it was really the
simplicity of the solution

and the ease of activating
features that really sold me.
When you look at that and then you look at

what's been this clear
roadmap of development
to get you to where you are now

and then what I see as the
roadmap moving forward,

and even the short time that
we've been on the platform,

we've seen so many of
those features activated.

It ended up being a really
easy decision for us
and the impact has been fabulous.

For customers, you want changes
like this to be invisible.
There was no downtime.
SLAs were maintained, which is really key,

but it's the insights that
we capture which is key now.
I'll talk a little bit about that later,
but for team members, yes,
a change to the way they work,

a different UI that they
need to engage with,
and many of them hadn't had a change
in their telephony platform for some time,
so there was a bit of that type of change,
but the insights we're now able
to provide them is phenomenal.
We're now able to use utterance capture

and also the transcription
from those interactions

to dig into process issues,
to product challenges,

all to make not only our team
members' experience great,

but most importantly,
our customers' experience
great as well.

- Connect is seriously one
of my favorite AWS services,

and the fact that you guys
consolidated, you said,

five contact centers to
Amazon Connect in two months,
that speaks volumes.

That's absolutely incredible
and actually very similar
to a lot of the other customers
that have been using this service,

is they just say, "It's
so easy to implement,"
and it blows my mind every single time
how quickly you guys can get this done.

I'm really glad to hear that
it was, in your own words,
one of the easiest tech implementations
you said you've completed with us.

Thank you so much, but
Brady, beyond Connect,

and I could honestly talk
about Connect all day,
I wanted to ask you,

where do you see the cloud
adding the most value to Vocus,
and what barriers,

'cause I know you guys
do have a few challenges,
does Vocus actually have to overcome
in order to achieve this value?

- Yeah, I think we know the
value of cloud better than most.

We're one of the most
interconnected telcos
in Australia and New Zealand
and we provide interconnectivity

between 150 data center locations,
18 of those are our own,

and a great deal of that rapid
acceleration in digitization
is in order to uptake cloud services,

so the things I'm personally
really excited about is

I know you have a great roadmap
of features and services

and capabilities that we're
only just starting to touch on,

and when I think about
that Future State program

that we're delivering and
how we're going to be able
to use our network performance data
and then connect that with the range of

other interaction data or
customer experience data,
it is really going to help us deliver

an enhanced level of service
to our end customers,
and we want that to be proactive.
We want it to be prompt and personable,

and so by connecting all of
this information together

and then leveraging those
cloud services available
from Amazon on top of that,

that's really going to help
us achieve better outcomes
for our customers.

As far as some of the barriers,
the biggest one for us is,
while we'll have those cloud services

across a range of the
segments that we support
and industries that we support,
there's a couple of tricky areas

where cloud just requires
more consideration,

and that's in the areas like
our Vocus Advanced Services,
which is a separate network
specifically for federal government,
where we've got real considerations

around providing secure and
sovereign infrastructure
for those customers.
It doesn't mean it's a complete inhibitor,
but at this stage, we haven't explored
a great deal of cloud in that area,

and that's because of some
of the security protocols
and stringent controls over partner

and third-party access
we've gotta consider
'cause that's the only sort of barrier,

but we can see cloud
being such a huge part
of the rest of our business.
- Thanks so much for sharing, Brady.
I love to hear both sides of the coin
and there's a lot of amazing stuff

and we know you're such
an advocate of the cloud,
but it is really important to hear about

some of the barriers that
companies might be facing,
but Brady, to round out this interview,

your role recently
expanded in the last year

to cover additional teams
and additional applications.
You've got a lot on at the moment,
so can you please talk to us about

how your leadership style has
changed through the pandemic
and how you're enjoying this new role?
- Yeah. Look, it has changed.

I'm really privileged to work
with the Vocus digital team
and have them added to the stable

that is the portfolio I've
got stewardship over in Vocus,

and they're a dedicated group
of digital professionals
across a range of applications
and they're balancing their stewardship

of some of that legacy
infrastructure we have

but also combining that with
this unparalleled enthusiasm

for deploying our Future
State network and platform.
It's really exciting to have that
as part of the portfolio now.

I guess, as a leader, the
thing I enjoy the most is

that intersection between
customer experience and tech

and being able to use those
rich customer insights

in order to influence the
behaviors and the actions

of a very clever digital
team is very rewarding.

To know that they're gonna be
able to deliver solutions for,
that benefit customers and team members

through those insights
is something that makes

the combination of these
two portfolios so important.

As for my leadership
style during the pandemic,
I think all leaders,

and people who even aren't
in leadership roles,

have gone through quite a
ride through the pandemic,
and the things that I know
will stay with me post pandemic

is really around a level of
authenticity in leadership.

I think we've seen people
experience a range of emotions
over the last couple of years
and being an authentic leader

that takes into account
the discrete situations

or the unique requirements
of either customers

or of the team members
we work with is key.

We've all probably heard
these heartbreaking stories

of loss, separation from
families and loved ones,
businesses that have been disrupted
and devastated by the pandemic,

and I think it's building
those personal relationships
to understand the challenges

that many customers and
team members have had.

It can't be underestimated
in how that helps you evolve
as a leader.
For me, being open in my approach

and building deeper, more
personal relationships

has helped me deal with those
situations more effectively,

and I think that is something
that's going to be with me

long after we stop talking
about this version of the virus.

The final bit is sort of
a sense of anticipation.
I don't know about you, Aley,

but this is fun, love
doing it on a screen,

but I would love to be doing
this face to face with you
over a coffee in the same room,

and I'm sort of like a
tightly wound spring.
I can't wait to see more of our customers.

I can't wait to see some
of our remote-based teams,
both here and over in the Philippines,

and I've missed that buzz
from connecting in groups,

collaborating, developing
ideas, creating solutions.
That's something that I think

we've learnt to deal with
effectively in front of screens,
but I think everybody's desperate
to do more of that face to face.

I look forward to maybe doing
another version of these,

Aley, face to face in the
same room over that coffee

and talking more about what
we're going to do at Vocus.
- Absolutely, Brady.
Thank you so much for coming on the show.
I could honestly talk to you all day,

so we definitely have to
do a round two in person

when the whole world calms
down, but thank you so much.
Vocus is so lucky to have you.

Your team's so lucky
to have you, and yeah,
if anyone has any questions at all,

please pop them in the
comment section below
and we'll get back to you.
Thank you so much.
